Context:
The Early Childhood Education program at the college offers several field education options: an accelerated 16-month option (four continuous semesters), a Fast-Track 10-month option for those with a diploma or degree in a related field, and a standard option with a seven-week field placement each semester. Students will have the opportunity to work with children of different age groups in various settings. The college operates Ontario's largest network of college-run lab school child care centres, which serve over 1,000 children and their families each year. These child care centres are located across Toronto.

Graduates of the program may find employment in various sectors such as child care centres, early years centres, full-day kindergarten, parent resource centres, pediatric playrooms, special education settings, integrated kindergartens, therapeutic nursery programs, and in-home care.

Some field placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19. Students not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may be unable to complete their program's required field placement component in the regularly scheduled time frame.

There is no specific mention of the name or type of degree/diploma offered by the college in the text provided.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Early Childhood Education Program C100 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
This text is about an Early Childhood Education program offered at a college in Ontario, Canada. Completion of the program makes graduates eligible for entrance to Ontario's College of Early Childhood Educators as a Registered Early Childhood Educator. Graduates will learn to design curriculum for child-centered, play-based learning, support children's development, build relationships with families and communities, and create safe, healthy environments.

Required courses in the program include ECE 1000 to ECE 2061, some of which are repeated in different semesters. These courses cover professional development workshops, field practices, health and safety, interpersonal communication, foundations of Early Childhood Education, observation, planning and evaluation, anti-racism, inclusion, policy advocacy, legislation, working with families, and curriculum theory. Students who complete the program with a GPA of 2.5 or higher may apply to the Bachelor of Early Childhood Education - Honours (Degree Completion) program.

Additional courses mentioned include PSY 1075 (Infant and Child Development), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), GSSC 1064 (Introduction to Sociology), and a course named GNED. The text does not provide specific details on the length of the program or contact information for the college.

Context:
Program Offered: Early Childhood Education (ECE)
Semester 4 Courses:
- ECE 1184: Integrated Seminar IV
- ECE 2017: Field Practice IV
- ECE 2048: Policy, Advocacy, and Legislation
- ECE 2049: Inclusion in Early Childhood
- ECE 2050: Working with Families
- ECE 2053: Curriculum Theory
- ECE 2057: Current Issues

General Education Electives:
- GNED (Generic name for General Education Elective courses)

Placement Test Requirement: COMM 1000 Introduction to College Communication (Extra course, doesn't count towards graduation)

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Create learning contexts to enable, build and maintain caring, responsive relationships...
2. Co-create, facilitate and reflect upon inquiry and play-based early years and child care programs...
3. Co-design and maintain inclusive early-learning environments...
4. Collaborate with children, families, colleagues, agencies and community partners...
5. Use observation strategies to identify children's strengths and challenges...
6. Use professional communication in interactions with various entities...
7. Act in accordance with relevant legislation, regulations, and codes of ethics...
8. Identify, report and document when a child is in a perceived risk situation.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Early Childhood Education Program C100 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The College offers early childhood education programs with a focus on identifying and reporting situations of perceived risk for, or actual neglect or abuse of children in accordance with legislation and college codes. Tuition fees for domestic students are estimated at $3,998 for the first two semesters starting Fall 2023, while international students pay approximately $18,130 for the same period. The program is eligible for OSAP funding for applicants who meet the eligibility criteria. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U) and three additional grade 12 C, U, M or grade 11 C, U or M credits. Mature students can take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade to meet the credit requirement. Tuition fees are subject to change without notice.

[College of Early Childhood Education, program in early childhood education, tuition fees, domestic students: $3,998 (Fall 2023), international students: $18,130 (Fall 2023), OSAP funding, Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, admission requirements]

Context:
Program Information: Early Childhood Education

Key Information:
- Students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to meet English credit requirements. Grade 11 English (ENG3C) cannot be used toward meeting additional credits.
- College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions. Check the Transfer Guide for more information.
- International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
- Field placement is a mandatory component of the program, and students must complete standard first aid with CPR level C course, police vulnerable sector check, and medical clearance prior to beginning field placement. Students unable to provide completed field clearance documents may be unable to complete the program. For more information, email ece@georgebrown.ca.
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Contact the School of Early Childhood at 416-415-5000, ext. 2310 or email ece@georgebrown.ca for more information.
- Visit the International Contact Us page to contact international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin.
- Related programs: Early Childhood Education.
